p.seg: [...] I heard this,
that Ji is from an great family East of the River,
if you will hereby enact (this offer)
and serve him as a dignitary,
I will give you instruction (about governance).
Ji Heng employed Zhong Gong as Head ministers
Zhong Gong told Confucius
saying:
Ji […] employed me, Yong,
as I have followed in the entourage of Great ministers,
but as I am hesitant and stupid,
and I fear to bring shame upon you,
I want because of you to decline.
Confucius said:
"You, Yong [...]
our master (=Ji Xuanzi) has a miriad servants to lead (=help) you,
employing you to be an elder (=an official in charge) of his family,
Zhong Gong asked:
"May I ask what should take precedence in government?"
"To treat the old (with the respect they deserve) as old persons,
to treat the young with kindness,
to give precedence [rely on] the officers in charge,
to promote worthiness and talent,
be indulgent with minor mistakes
but to mention (point out) major crimes.
[...] crimes, is the beginning of government.
Zhong Gong said:
"As for treating the old (with the respect they deserve) as old persons,
and for treating the young with kindness,
I have already heard your command.
Now, as for relying on the officers in charge,
how to do it?"
Confucius said:
"As the people are at peace with the old
and find change hard,
to create (major) changes would not do,
only by proceeding as a winding snake (=subtly?) there can be success,
therefore you cannot but relying on the officers in charge.
Zhong Gong said:
“I am not bright,
even if there are worthy and talented people,
I would not recognize and promote them.
May I ask how to proceed to promote talent?”
Confucius said:
“Now, worthy and talented people cannot be concealed.
Promote the ones you know,
for the ones you do not know,
(how) would people leave them aside?”
Zhong Gong said:
"To be indulgent with minor mistakes and to pardon (point out) major crimes,
then how can the people follow (=be compliant)?
Confucius said:
"Mountains sometimes collapse,
rivers sometimes run dry,
even the sun and the moon and the heavenly bodies diverge,
as for the people there are not those without fault,
the worthies [...]
Zhou Gong said:
"May I ask about the occupations of the people."
Confucius said:
"Nice question!
It is worth teaching,
the ruler [...] should not himself be lazy.
In the past the enlightened kings of the three dynasties possessed everything within the four seas,
and would even cause to come [...]
"Yong, you know it."
Zhong Gong said:
"I have not heard about it."
Confucius said:
"Sacrifices are the root of outmost respect,
the means by which one gives stability to the living,
one cannot but be cautious (about them);
mourning is the completion of outmost care,
it is the means by which one gives completion to the (care for the) dead,
one cannot but be cautious (about it);
acting,
humbly looking for instruction
[...] if punishments and governance are not slack,
virtue and teachings will not be weary.
Zhong Gong said:
“As for these three things,
I have heard your command,
may I ask about how to lead the people and exhalt virtue?”
Confucius said:
"Display it (=virtue) and cause them to submit,
spread it out softly and let them employ their strenghts with docility.
Even if they have faulty virtue, their [...]
[...] discarded,
it will not reach its completion.
Dominating single-handedly and oppressing people,
it will be difficult to govern."
Confucius said:
"Yong, those that in antiquity served the ruler,
used loyalty and respect,
even though it is difficult,
you should use [...]
[...] If those above and those below treat each other with loyalty,
then the people will happily receive education,
harming [.] will not [...] ???
If one faces them with what is good every day,
what is taught will in every case reach completion;
if one faces them every day with what is not good,
what is taught will all crumble down,
is it admissible not to be careful?"
Zhong Gong said:
“The ruler of nowadays when they employ people,
do not use up their [...]
their faults."
Zhong Gong said:
"The rulers of nowadays,
are obstinate in their mistakes and quick in their analyses (=quick witted),
it is difficult thereby to have them accept remonstrances."
Confucius said:
"The rulers of nowadays [...]
the most proper and pliant,
if you would teach them and employ them,
the ruler would not have anything with which to oppress people.
Now you will serve as minister of the ruler's place (=family),
if you do your outmost
and use the greatest care,
the three harms will approach treatment (?) (=be easy to deal with).
